conclusion: For an ideal gas, the specific internal energy (or internal energy per unit mass) depends only on temperature: U = U(T).
In the p-V diagram every point (p, V) that lies on a given adiabat satisfies p V^Î³ = constant (Î³ = C_p/C_v > 1).
Points c and a lie on two different adiabats.
p_c > p_a (the curve through c is everywhere above the curve through a).

premise: p_c > p_a at the same volume
conclusion: T_c > T_a (use the ideal-gas relation pV = nRT).

premise: U depends only on T, and T_c > T_a
conclusion: The larger temperature implies the larger internal energy.

premise: The larger temperature implies the larger internal energy.
conclusion: U_c > U_a (the internal energy at state c is greater than at state a).
